001package io.github.ai4ci.util;
002
003import java.util.stream.IntStream;
004
005import io.github.ai4ci.functions.EmpiricalDistribution;
006import io.github.ai4ci.functions.LinkFunction;
007
008/**
009 * Utility class for generating and working with exotic distributions.
010 *
011 * <p>
012 * Currently includes a method for generating the distribution of distances on a
013 * square grid normalised by the length of the hypoteneuse, which can be used
014 * for modelling spatial interactions in a grid-based environment.
015 *
016 * @author Rob Challen
017 */
018public class ExoticDistributions {
019
020        /**
021         * The distribution of distances on a square grid normalised by length of
022         * hypoteneuse. This distribution arises when considering the distances
023         * between points uniformly distributed on a unit square, and normalising by
024         * the maximum distance (the length of the hypoteneuse, which is sqrt(2)).
025         * The distribution can be used for modelling spatial interactions in a
026         * grid-based environment, where the distance between points is relevant for
027         * interaction probabilities.
028         *
029         * @return an empirical distribution representing the normalised distance
030         *         distribution on a square grid
031         *
032         */
033        public static EmpiricalDistribution getEuclidianDistanceDistribution() {
034                Sampler rng = Sampler.getSampler();
035                int s = 100000;
036                double[] data = new double[s];
037                IntStream.range(0, s).parallel().forEach(i -> {
038                        data[i] = Math.sqrt(
039                                        Math.pow(rng.uniform() - rng.uniform(), 2)
040                                                        + Math.pow(rng.uniform() - rng.uniform(), 2)
041                        ) / Math.sqrt(2);
042                });
043                return EmpiricalDistribution.fromData(LinkFunction.LOGIT, data);
044        }
045
046}
